questions.question_text: A new HTTPS web service is being deployed on a server. Which of the following commands should the Linux administrator use to ensure traffic is able to flow through the system firewall to the new service?

discussion.content: Answer is B

Correct Answer: B. iptables ג€"A INPUT ג€"p tcp --dport 443 ג€"j ACCEPT

For HTTPS it would be TCP port 443. You will need to use -A flag. 
-A --append Add one or more rules to the end of the selected chain.

The answer is B.. iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT
-A INPUT(from firewall to the server)
-p(port/ protocol tcp)
--dport(Destination port)
443(HTTPS)
-j ACCEPT(Allow the request)
The answer is B.. The HTTPS is a tcp protocol port 443

Listing 24.10: Modifying the firewall with the iptables command
$ iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT

Reference: CompTIA Linux+ Study Guide, 4th Edition, Sybex Wiley

Selected Answer: B
Can't be C because "iptables -I"needs rolenum, that's why the only valid solution is "B" using "-A" (append)
Answer is B

choices.D: iptables ג€"A OUTPUT ג€"p tcp --dport 443 ג€"j ACCEPT
choices.B: iptables ג€"A INPUT ג€"p tcp --dport 443 ג€"j ACCEPT
choices.A: iptables ג€"I OUTPUT ג€"p tcp --sport 443 ג€"j ACCEPT

discussion.content:
The kill command sends a signal to specified processes or process groups, causing them to act according to the signal. When the signal is not specified, it defaults to -15 (-TERM).
The most commonly used signals are:

1 (HUP) - Reload a process.

SIGHUP
The SIGHUP (“hang-up”) signal is used to report that the user’s terminal is disconnected, perhaps because a network or telephone connection was broken. For more information about this, see Control Modes.

This signal is also used to report the termination of the controlling process on a terminal to jobs associated with that session; this termination effectively disconnects all processes in the session from the controlling terminal

https://www.gnu.org/software/libc/manual/html_node/Termination-Signals.html

questions.question_text:
An administrator has modified the configuration file for a service. The service is still running but is not using the new configured values. Which of the following will
BEST remediate this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This is definitely A.

Selected Answer: A
definetly A.
https://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/understanding-etcshadow-file/

The administrator needs to look at the /etc/shadow file to view the encrypted passwords of users. 
So the correct answer is option A

questions.question_text: An administrator needs to see a list of the system user's encrypted passwords. Which of the following Linux files does the administrator need to read?

choices.B: # grep ג€"i IP ג€${ip addr show} production.company.comג€ > /etc/resolv.conf
choices.C: # ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0 && rndc reload production.company.com

questions.question_text: A Linux administrator is setting up a testing environment and needs to connect to a separate testing server using the production server name. The administrator needs to override the hostname that the DNS is returning in order to use the test environment. Which of the following commands should be run on each of the testing systems to BEST meet this goal?

discussion.content: Shouldn't it be D?
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer right?

Selected Answer: D
key work “override dns” and that can be accomplished by using host file … D for sure

Selected Answer: D
D, is correct.

D - hostnamectl is for your own host name and it modifies the /etc/hostname file (your name). The /etc/hosts file, as lizano stated maps hostnames and IPs of other systems and has a priority over DNS.
It´s D. The hosts file has priority over a DNS.
The correct options are A and B GNOME & KDE
